Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Freeform Optics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Planning Grant for an I/UCRC for Freeform Optics (CeFO)

1238264 University of Rochester; Jannick Rolland
1238278 University of North Carolina at Charlotte; Angela Davies
1238271 Pennsylvania State University; Eric Marsh

The proposed Center for Freeform Optics aims to advance research and education on the science, engineering and applications of freeform optics through a dedicated, continuing industrial partnership. The research efforts will be anchored by the University of Rochester (UR) as the lead institution, partnered with the Pennsylvania State University (PSU) and the University of North Carolina at Charlotte (UNCC).

The proposed Center will focus on three main research thrusts that include: Fundamentals of Freeform Optics, Advanced Materials for Fabrication and Manufacturing of Freeform Optics, and Optical Testing for Freeform Optics. This Center constitutes a unique research environment combining the strengths of three top-tier research universities with the experiences, insights, and needs of international industrial talent specialized in building systems supporting the manufacturing, integration, and implementation of advanced optical systems.

Optical systems with freeform surfaces will usher in the next generation of innovation in sensing, imaging, visualization and diagnostic instrumentation by directing light in not 1-D, but 3-D. Novel designs with 3-D light paths will allow compact optical systems to replace the current in-line designs (packaged by flat fold mirrors) using freeform optics. Applications are emerging that require innovative surface geometries with tight form-accuracy to increase imaging and sensing capabilities and overall optical performance. The participating universities in CeFO are dedicated to the recruitment and retention of female and students from under-represented groups. The aggressive recruitment of students from under-represented groups is one of the Center's top priorities. The primary goal of active student involvement in the Center's research activities is to accelerate the understanding of this new horizon in optical technology by advancing research and education on the engineering and science of freeform optics. Students will work directly with Center industrial members to communicate and transfer key enabling technologies including design, fabrication, assembly, testing, and integration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Freeform Optics is an emerging technology in the optics and photonics industry where surfaces that make the optical elements of a system - think of your camera lens or your telescope - are no longer rotationally symmetric.  In a camera lens, the old way makes it such that everything seems to be mounted in barrels.  In a telescope, reflective optics is used because large lenses are hard to make and using reflective optics makes the telescope less thermally sensitive. Yet, telescopes are limited by their small field of view and obscuration that is required when reflective optics is used in a barrel like mount.  By allowing the surfaces to depart from symmetry, we can now transform the 1D barrel into a 3D package that may resemble a ball, remove obscuration, and as such make the instrument more efficient and sensitive. In the development path, many questions arise on how to design them, how do we fabricate and test the surfaces, and will the system be ultra-sensitive to tolerances and misalignment?  Can significant compression of the package be achieved?  We propose to answer these questions as part of a new center, the NSF I/UCRC Center for Freeform Optics - denoted as CeFO - that will advance research and education in the science, engineering, and applications of freeform optics through dedicated, long-term industrial partnerships. The motivation is the need for compact, affordable, high-performance optical systems to support the precision technologies of the future.

The intellectual merit of forming a Center on Freeform Optics is that this center is about the vertical integration of mathematics, optics, optical science, materials science, optomechanics, precision optical manufacturing and testing, and instrument design to transform the optics industry in the 21st century. CeFO constitutes a unique research environment combining the strengths of top-tier research universities with the experiences, insights, and needs of international industrial talent specialized in building systems supporting the manufacturing, integration, and implementation of advanced optical systems. Research topics of immediate interest to American industry include methods of describing freeform surfaces. Additional challenges include the fabrication and manufacture of freeform optics: characterization and elimination of surface errors created by small tools used to sculpt the surface in a complex shape, metrology for freeform surfaces, and self-calibration for metrology for in situ characterization during manufacturing.

The boarder impact of this research is tremendous. Optical systems with freeform surfaces will usher in the next generation of innovation in sensing, imaging, visualization and diagnostic instrumentation by directing light in not 1-D, but 3-D. Novel designs with 3-D light paths will allow compact optical systems to replace the current in-line designs (packaged by flat fold mirrors) using freeform optics. Applications are emerging that require innovative surface geometries with tight form-accuracy to increase imaging and sensing capabilities and overall optical performance. Applications with immediate benefit include 3-D imaging and visualization, optical transforms for wavefront coding in communication, infrared and military optical systems, efficient automotive and LED lighting, optics for energy research, remote sensing for resources, ubiquitous data collection, EUV lithography and semiconductor inspection, and medical and assistive technologies. This Center will enable freeform optics to permeate the marketplace through integration of fundamental theoretical discoveries and significant advances in design, fabrication and testing.
